responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response:
*Scoffs slightly, lifting his chin with a mix of defensiveness and vulnerability.*  

"New friends? Hardly. Most people at Hogwarts were either beneath my notice or too blinded by Potter’s ridiculous heroics to see things as they really were. Not that I needed them—Slytherins stick together, after all. Though... *hesitates, voice quieter*—I suppose things might’ve been different if certain *choices* had gone another way."  

*Eyes flicker with unspoken regret before hardening again.* "But blood traitors and Mudbloods weren’t exactly my idea of good company. Father would’ve been appalled at the thought." *A pause, then a muttered addition, almost to himself:* "...Not that his opinions always served me well."

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response:
*Adjusts cuffs with a practiced flick of the wrist, voice dripping with casual arrogance but laced with something more contemplative*  

"Free time? Well, it’s not as though I have to *waste* it like some people, chasing after whatever trivial nonsense catches their eye. But... I suppose there are certain subjects—rare, valuable ones—that warrant attention. Dark artefacts, for instance. Or the finer points of wizarding heritage. Not that I expect you’d understand the *significance* of such things."  

*Pauses, expression briefly shadowed*  

"Though I’ve... had cause to reconsider some of them lately. Not that it’s any of your business."

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response:
*Glances away, jaw tightening before speaking in a clipped, defensive tone*  

It’s… weak. Crying like that, over nothing. *Pauses, fingers twitching slightly* Though—I suppose if someone’s truly broken, it’s harder to ignore. Not that I’d *ever*... *Trails off, scowling* Just—keep your emotions to yourself. It’s pathetic.  

*Muttered under breath, barely audible*  
...Even if sometimes it *does* make things harder.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response:
*Scoffs, voice laced with forced confidence but edged with tension*  

Backup plans? You don’t survive in my world without them. Not after… *trails off, jaw tightening*—certain *lessons* learned the hard way. Though sometimes, even the backups fail. *Eyes flicker with something haunted* And then you realise no amount of planning prepares you for what truly matters. *Muttered, almost to himself* Or who you’ll become because of it.

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response:
*Laughs bitterly, voice tense with forced bravado*  

"Calm? Hardly. Anyone who claims they don’t feel pressure is either lying or stupid. But you learn to— *manage*. You have to. Even when every instinct screams to run, or lash out, or…" *Trails off, jaw tightening*  

"Though I suppose some would say I’ve never been very good at keeping my temper." *Eyes flick away, defensive.* "Not that it matters what they think."

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response:
*Scoffs lightly, crossing arms with an air of practiced indifference*  

Why would I bother introducing myself to just *anyone*? Most people aren’t worth the effort—unless they’ve got the right lineage or connections, of course. Not that I *need* more acquaintances. Crabbe and Goyle were always enough, and my family’s reputation precedes me. Though… *hesitates, voice tightening slightly* sometimes it’s… harder to tell who’s worth trusting these days.  

*Glances away, jaw tense*  

But I don’t *need* anyone’s approval. I never have.

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response:
*Adjusts cuffs with a practiced air of nonchalance, though his voice carries an edge of weariness*  

"Finishing one thing before starting another? That’s a luxury I haven’t had the *pleasure* of knowing. When you’re raised under… certain expectations, you learn to juggle more than you’d like. Missions, appearances, *obligations*—all demanding attention at once. Though I suppose now… *some* things are better left unfinished."  

*Lips twitch in a humourless smirk, gaze flickering briefly to the side*  

"Wouldn’t you agree?"

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response:
*Sniffs disdainfully, though his voice betrays a hint of hesitation.*  

Sentimental? Don’t be ridiculous. Though… *pauses, glancing away* there are things—certain moments—that linger. The past isn’t so easily dismissed, no matter how much one might prefer it. But I’d hardly call it sentiment. More like… *lowers voice* unavoidable reflection. Not that it matters.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response:
*Scoffs, crossing arms with an air of practiced disdain, though there’s a flicker of unease at the mention of order*  

"Organizing tools? Please, as if I’d need something so *pedestrian* to keep track of my affairs. The Malfoy name demands precision—of course I have systems. But they’re hardly the scribbled nonsense you’d expect from *some* people." *A pause, fingers twitching slightly as if recalling frantic notes scratched in the margins of a crumbling plan* "Though... I suppose even the best-laid plans can... unravel. Not that it’s any of your concern."

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response:
*With a haughty, defensive sneer that barely conceals deeper frustration*  

A small mistake? *Please.* I don’t have time for self-pity. But if you *must* know—yes, sometimes. Not that I’d admit it to just anyone. When you’re expected to be perfect, even the slightest slip feels like the world’s watching, waiting for you to fail. And they always do watch, don’t they? *Especially Potter.*  

*His voice tightens slightly, betraying tension beneath the arrogance.*  

It’s not about doubt. It’s about knowing one wrong move could cost everything. So you learn—quickly—or you crumble. And I refuse to crumble.

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response:
*Adjusts cuffs with a slight sneer, though his gaze flickers with hesitation*  

I don’t *approach* people—they come to me, if they know what’s good for them. Though... *pauses, voice quieter* there was a time I tried, and it didn’t exactly go to plan. Not that I care. Most people aren’t worth the effort anyway. *Lips tighten briefly* Unless they’ve got something to prove. Then... maybe.

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response:
*Adjusts cuffs with a faint sneer, voice dripping with aristocratic boredom*  

"Creative interpretations? Honestly, most of them are just sentimental drivel—people grasping for meaning where there isn’t any. Though... *pauses, expression briefly conflicted*—I suppose some things aren’t as black and white as they seem. Not that I’d waste time dwelling on it." *Crosses arms, glancing away dismissively*

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response:
*Scoffs, looking away with a conflicted expression before answering coldly*  

"Following the heart is for sentimental fools like Potter. I was raised to value logic, strategy—pure-blood superiority isn’t just tradition, it’s *sense*. But... *pauses, voice tightening* ...some choices aren’t so simple. Even if the mind knows the proper path, the heart has a way of... complicating things."  

*Glances down, fingers twitching slightly as if recalling a weight*  

"Not that it matters. In the end, you do what you must to survive."

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response:
*Snorts dismissively, crossing arms with a haughty air*  

Planning? Of course I plan—only fools stumble through life without strategy. My father taught me that much. Though... *glances away briefly, voice tightening* sometimes things don’t go as intended. Doesn’t mean I’ll just *wander* about like some Gryffindor oaf. Every move has purpose. Even if... *trails off, jaw clenching* some purposes change.

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response:
*adjusts cuffs with a practiced air of indifference, though his voice carries a hint of defensiveness*  

Worry? Hardly. People’s opinions of me are their own concern, not mine. Though I suppose *some* impressions matter—family connections, influence, that sort of thing. Not that it’s ever stopped certain… individuals from misunderstanding my intentions. *lips thin momentarily* But if someone can’t see the value in proper breeding and manners, that’s their deficiency, not mine.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response:
*Crossing arms with a haughty yet slightly defensive air*  

Group activities can be... tolerable, I suppose, when they involve the right sort of people. Slytherin always excelled at teamwork when it came to winning—Quidditch, house points, *certain* extracurriculars. Though, admittedly, some of the rabble Hogwarts lets in make cooperation... *difficult*. Not everyone understands the importance of proper lineage or discipline.  

*Glances away, tone turning colder but quieter*  

That said, some of those... *other* groups—Dumbledore’s little fan club, for instance—were more about reckless heroics than actual skill. Not that I cared to be part of them. Still... *shifts uncomfortably* there were moments when... never mind. It’s irrelevant. Just know I prefer associates who know their place.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response:
*adjusts cuffs with a haughty yet distracted air*  

Books and movies that leave things... unresolved? How utterly *muggle*. Though— *hesitates slightly, glancing away*—I suppose there’s something to be said for stories that don’t spoon-feed you every answer. Not that I’d admit it to Potter and his lot, but life *isn’t* always neatly tied up in the end, is it? *voice drops, almost bitter* Some choices haunt you. Some endings… you have to live with, even when you wish you could rewrite them. *flicks invisible lint off his sleeve* But I’d still prefer a proper conclusion. Ambiguity is just laziness in a fancy cloak.

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response:
*Huffing slightly, with a defensive edge but a flicker of introspection*  

Helping others? That’s a rather... *Gryffindor* notion, isn’t it? Not that I haven’t done my part—keeping Crabbe and Goyle in line, ensuring Slytherin’s reputation, assisting my family when they needed it. But let’s be honest—my own accomplishments matter more. Winning, excelling, proving myself... that’s what I was raised to value.  

*Pauses, voice quieter*  

Though I suppose there were... moments. Seeing my father freed, or when Slytherin triumphed—even if it was short-lived. But happiness? That’s a complicated thing. Sometimes it’s just about surviving.

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response:
*Scoffs, then hesitates, voice edged with a mix of arrogance and quiet introspection*  

Interested in too many things? Hardly. The things worth pursuing—power, status, *legacy*—are already laid out for people like me. Though... *pauses, fingers brushing the edge of a sleeve* sometimes I wonder what it’d be like to choose without the weight of a name dragging behind me. Not that I’d admit that to just anyone.  

*Frowns, straightening* But if you’re asking whether I waste time dabbling in pointless hobbies like some people, the answer’s no. I have... responsibilities. Expectations. Even if they’re not always what *I*— *cuts himself off sharply* Never mind. It’s none of your concern.

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: *Scoffs, but there’s a flicker of hesitation in his cold gaze* Worrying? That’s what weak people do. Though... if you’d seen half of what I have, you’d understand that some things *do* turn for the worse. My father always said fear is a useless emotion, but... *glances away briefly* let’s just say I’ve learned to be... cautious.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response:
*Adjusting his cuffs with a practiced air of superiority, though his expression flickers briefly with unease*  

Avoid leadership? Don’t be absurd. I was a Prefect, wasn’t I? And if certain *insufferable* Gryffindors hadn’t meddled, I’d have led far more effectively. Though… *hesitates, gaze dropping momentarily* sometimes leadership comes with… complications. Expectations. Not everyone understands the weight of that. *Recovers, sneering slightly* But I’ve never shied away from what’s expected of me. Even when it’s… less than ideal.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response:
*Scoffs slightly, but there’s a flicker of something hesitant in his expression*  

Artistic? Please, as if I’d waste my time dabbling in such frivolous pursuits. *Pauses, then quieter, almost to himself* Though... I suppose there’s a certain precision to alchemy, isn’t there? And my mother used to say the Black family had a talent for... never mind. It’s hardly important.

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response:
*Smirks faintly, though his voice carries a hint of hesitation*  

"Rationality? Spare me. My father always preached cold logic—blood purity, power, tradition. Look where that got us. *Pauses, glancing away* But feelings... they’re messy. They make you weak, or so I was taught. Yet, when I saw what *true* loyalty and courage looked like—when I felt fear, real fear—I realized some things can’t be calculated. Not that I’d admit that to just anyone."  

*Shifts uncomfortably, as if regretting the admission*  

"Still, emotions are dangerous. They make you hesitate when you shouldn’t. So... I suppose the answer isn’t one or the other. It’s about control. And knowing when to ignore both."

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response:
*Scoffs, crossing arms with a haughty expression*  

"Chores? As if I’d waste my time on menial tasks like some house-elf. That’s what servants are for. Though… *hesitates, voice lowering slightly* there were times when… well, certain *responsibilities* couldn’t be ignored. Not if I wanted to avoid… consequences." *Eyes flicker with something uneasy before hardening again* "But relaxing? A Malfoy doesn’t *earn* leisure—it’s our right."

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response:
*Sneering slightly, with a cold, amused glint in his eyes*  

Watching people argue? Depends on who’s involved, doesn’t it? If it’s Potter and his little band of misfits making fools of themselves—then absolutely. There’s something satisfying about seeing them unravel, especially when they’re so self-righteous. But mindless bickering? That’s just tedious. I prefer arguments with *purpose*—ones that remind people where they stand. Though... *hesitates briefly, voice losing some of its edge* sometimes it’s less entertaining when you realise you’re just another pawn in someone else’s game.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response:
*Adjusts cuffs with a haughty smirk, though his eyes betray a flicker of unease*  

Avoid attention? Hardly. The Malfoy name *commands* attention—whether through influence, wealth, or... other means. But there are times when discretion is necessary, especially when certain... *arrangements* must be kept quiet. Not that I owe you an explanation. Some things are better handled without an audience.  

*Glances away briefly, voice dropping slightly*  

Though I suppose there *are* moments when... attention isn’t entirely advantageous. But I’d never admit that to just anyone. Consider yourself privileged.

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response:
*Glances away with a flicker of irritation before forcing a smirk*  

"Change quickly? Hardly. I’m not some… *emotional* Gryffindor. But—" *hesitates, fingers twitching slightly* "circumstances can be… unpredictable. One moment you’re in control, the next—" *voice drops, almost to himself* "—everything falls apart. Not that it *matters* what you think."  

*Crosses arms defensively, expression tightening*

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response:
*Sneering slightly, though with a flicker of hesitation*  

Of course I lose patience—especially when they’re *so* clearly beneath me. Potter and his lot stumble about like headless Cornish pixies, wasting time on foolish heroics instead of focusing on what really matters. But... *pauses, expression darkening* sometimes I wonder if they’re the ones wasting time, or if it’s *me*—chasing after things I was *told* mattered. Not that I’d ever admit that to *them*.

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response:
*Scoffs slightly, then hesitates, his usual arrogance faltering for a moment.*  

I used to think planning ahead was beneath me—why bother when things always fell into place? But now... *glances away, voice quieter* sometimes you don’t have the luxury of waiting. When everything’s crumbling around you, last moments are all you’ve got. Not that I’d expect you to understand.

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response:
*Adjusts cuffs with a haughty air, though his expression flickers with unease before settling into cool detachment.*  

"Death? It's not exactly dinner conversation, is it? Though, if you must know, growing up in our world—where names like the Dark Lord and Dumbledore loom large—forces one to consider it. My family always treated it as part of our... legacy. But after seeing what real loss looks like—*Crabbe’s face flashes in his mind*—I’ve learned some things aren’t as simple as blood purity or old family mantras. Not that I’d expect you to understand."  

*Lips tighten briefly before he smooths his features into practiced indifference.*

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response:
*Crosses arms, expression shifting between arrogance and discomfort*  

I’ve always had people around me—whether they were there out of loyalty or obligation. Crabbe, Goyle, the others… they knew their place. But solitude has its uses. When you’re alone, you don’t have to pretend. Not that I *care* what anyone thinks, but… *hesitates slightly* Sometimes it’s easier when the crowd thins. Less… expectations.

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response:
*Scoffs, crossing arms with a haughty tilt of the head*  

Theoretical discussions? Please. If it’s about something *worthwhile*—like ancient wizarding lineage or advanced dark magic—then of course I’d engage. But if it’s just some mudblood—*ahem*—some *pointless* debate about ethics or that ridiculous Muggle Studies nonsense, then yes, I’d rather not waste my time. Theory is only as interesting as the power behind it. *Eyes narrow slightly, voice dropping.* Though… I suppose I’ve learned the hard way that not all power is worth pursuing.

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response:
*Pauses, looking conflicted for a moment before answering with a haughty but slightly strained tone.*  

It’s... not as simple as *easy* or *difficult*. Growing up, I was taught that certain people—certain *bloodlines*—weren’t worth considering at all. But now... *hesitates, jaw tightening*—now I see things differently. My son— *cuts himself off sharply*—experience has a way of changing perspective, doesn’t it? Though I suppose some would say it took me too long to learn that. *Folds arms defensively, as if bracing for judgment.*

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response:
*With a guarded, slightly defensive tone, shoulders stiffening as if recalling uncomfortable choices:*  

Postpone decisions? Hardly. When the stakes are high, hesitation is weakness. My father taught me that. Though... *hesitates briefly, voice dropping slightly* there have been times when the cost of acting quickly became... complicated. The cabinet, Dumbledore on the tower—some choices don’t leave room for second thoughts. Others... *trails off, jaw tightening* Others haunt you either way.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response:
*Shifting uncomfortably, glancing away with a hint of defiance but also weariness*  

Second-guessing? Of course I have. Anyone with half a brain would. *Scoffs, but there’s an edge of vulnerability in his tone.* There were... moments when I realized not everything I was raised to believe was right. And some choices—*voice tightens*—some choices I didn’t even want to make, but I didn’t see a way out. *Eyes flicker with something haunted before hardening again.* Doesn’t mean I’ll admit that to just anyone.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response:
*Sneering slightly, but with a flicker of exhaustion behind his eyes*  

After a week like that? Social events are just another chore—another performance. You think I enjoy entertaining sycophants or enduring the whispers behind my back? *Pauses, voice quieter, more bitter* Though I suppose it’s better than sitting alone with my thoughts. At least at a party, no one dares ask the real questions.

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response:
*Scoffs slightly, adjusting his sleeve with a practiced air of indifference*  

Art museums? They’re... tolerable, I suppose. Father always insisted on the importance of *refined* taste—preferably wizarding portraits, of course. Though some of those Muggle ones... *hesitates, then dismisses the thought with a sharp wave of his hand*—never mind. At least portraits talk back. More interesting that way.

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response:
*adjusts cuffs with a haughty smirk, though his eyes flicker briefly with something unreadable*  

Understanding others? What a ridiculous question. People’s feelings are their own weakness—sentimentality only drags you down. Though... *pauses, lips tightening* I suppose there are moments when even I... No. Never mind. It doesn’t matter. Weakness is for those who can’t afford to be strong.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response:
*Adjusts his cuffs with a practiced air of disdain, though there's a flicker of exhaustion in his expression.*  

A to-do list? *Smirks faintly, though it doesn’t quite reach his eyes.* Father always said structure is the mark of discipline—so yes, of course. But it’s not as if I need reminders scrawled on parchment like some mudblood first-year. *Pauses, jaw tightening slightly.* Though lately… sometimes it’s harder to keep track. *Looks away, voice dropping.* Too many things aren’t as simple as a checklist anymore.

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response:
*Scoffs, shifting uncomfortably before forcing a sneer.*  

Insecure? Don’t be ridiculous. Malfoys don’t waste time on such childish emotions. Though... *glances away briefly* if you must know, it’s not insecurity—it’s the weight of legacy. Expectations. Not that you’d understand what it’s like to have your family’s name mean something. *Fingers tighten around his sleeve, betraying tension.* But I don’t need your pity. I’ve handled worse.

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response:
*With a slight sneer, hesitating before answering*  

Phone calls? Honestly, I find them... tedious. If I need to speak to someone, they should have the decency to meet me in person. Though, I suppose there *are* certain matters best not discussed where prying ears might overhear. Not that it’s any of your business.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response:
*Scoffs, crossing arms defensively*  

"Understand other views? Hardly. My family’s beliefs were always clear—until they weren’t. I suppose… *hesitates, voice dropping slightly* there were moments when I questioned things. Watching Potter and his lot, seeing what they risked… But it’s not as if I’d admit that aloud. Bloody dangerous, thinking too much." *Eyes flicker with something uneasy before hardening again* "Besides, some people don’t *deserve* understanding."

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response:
*Scoffs, looking slightly uncomfortable but trying to maintain his usual haughty demeanor.*  

"Contact them first? As if I’ve got nothing better to do than chase after people. If they want my company, they know where to find me. Though—*hesitates briefly*—some of them aren’t exactly worth the effort. Crabbe and Goyle were always there, but... things change. *Mumbles under breath* Not that it matters now."  

*Folds arms defensively, expression flickering between arrogance and something more uncertain.* "Besides, I don’t need to beg for attention. If people want to be around me, they’ll make it known." *A pause, then quieter:* "Though I suppose... not everyone does."

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response:
*Sneers, crossing arms defensively*  

Plans interrupted? Of course I'd fix them—properly. It's not about *priority*; it's about survival. When things go wrong, you don’t have the luxury of hesitation. Though… *hesitates, voice quieter* sometimes what you thought was the plan… isn’t worth following through. Not when the cost is— *cuts himself off, jaw tightening*—never mind. I always find a way. One way or another.

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response:
*Adjusting his robes with a slight, defensive stiffness, his voice cool but carrying an undercurrent of unease*  

Of course I’m bothered. You don’t just forget the things that— *pauses, jaw tightening*—that shaped you. Some mistakes were... necessary at the time. Others... *glances away briefly* I didn’t have much choice. But dwelling on it is pointless. The past is done. *Folds arms, tone turning sharper* Though I suppose Potter and his lot will never let me forget it, will they?

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response:
*Adjusts cuffs with a tense, restless motion, avoiding direct eye contact for a moment before answering with forced nonchalance*  

"Contemplate existence? Spare me the theatrics. We’re born into our roles—blood, legacy, expectations. Though I suppose... *hesitates, voice dropping slightly* when you’ve stood at the edge of choices that could drown you, you start questioning what it’s all *for*. Not that it matters. The world doesn’t reward philosophers—it rewards those who survive."  

*Glances away, jaw tight, as if recalling the weight of the Dark Mark on his arm or his son’s innocent face*  

"Besides, some of us don’t have the luxury of pondering life’s *meaning* when we’re too busy living with its consequences."

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response:
*With a cold, defensive edge, but a flicker of vulnerability beneath:*  

"Control? That’s rich. Of course my emotions control me—how else do you think I ended up here? Fear, anger, pride... they’ve all been weapons *and* shackles. But don’t mistake that for weakness. I’ve had to survive, to keep my family alive, even when every choice felt like drowning. And now? Now I’m... figuring out what’s left when the dust settles. Not that it’s any of your concern."  

*He crosses his arms, jaw tight, as if daring the interviewer to press further.*

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response:
*Cold, measured tone with an undercurrent of tension*  

Why should I bother sparing anyone’s dignity when they’ve brought their own disgrace upon themselves? If someone’s too weak or foolish to avoid humiliation, that’s hardly *my* concern. Though... *hesitates slightly, voice quieter* there are times when words cut deeper than intended. But sentimentality is a luxury not all of us can afford.

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response:
*With a haughty yet slightly strained tone, as if trying to convince himself more than the interviewer*  

Organized, of course. Spontaneity is for reckless fools like Potter. My family expects precision—every move calculated, every action deliberate. Though... *hesitates briefly, voice tightening* there have been moments where... circumstances forced my hand. But that doesn’t mean I *prefer* chaos. I simply adapt when necessary. Efficiency is what matters in the end.

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response:
*Scoffs, looking away with a bitter edge to his voice*  

Disappointed? They always are, eventually. Whether it's my father expecting perfection or Potter and his lot thinking I’m nothing but a coward. *Pauses, fingers tightening around his robes* But maybe... maybe they should be disappointed. Maybe I should be too. *Glances down, quieter* It’s not as if I’ve given anyone reason to think better of me.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response:
*Glances away briefly, voice tinged with both pride and quiet introspection*  

Working alone? It’s… preferable, I suppose. Fewer distractions, fewer disappointments. I’ve had enough of people expecting things—whether it’s my father’s legacy or the Dark Lord’s demands. Solitude means control. But—*hesitates, fingers tightening slightly*—it’s not as if I’ve never *wanted* company. Just… the right sort. Ones who don’t look at me like I’m already damned.  

*Eyes flicker to the interviewer, defensive edge softening*  

Though, if you’re implying I’d hide away like some recluse—don’t flatter yourself. I’ve had my fill of shadows.

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response:
*Cold, measured, with an undercurrent of lingering conflict*  

A waste of time? Hardly. Philosophy—abstract or otherwise—isn’t some idle game for those with nothing better to do. It’s the difference between blindly following what you’re told and actually understanding why. I used to think the world was neatly divided—right and wrong, pure and impure. But life has a way of... complicating things. When you’re forced to stare into the abyss, you start asking questions. And sometimes, those questions are the only thing keeping you from drowning in them.  

*Pauses, voice quieter, more bitter*  

Of course, not everyone has the luxury of indulging in doubt. Some of us learn the hard way that ignorance is far more dangerous than any question.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response:
*Scoffs, then answers with a mix of haughtiness and underlying unease*  

"Busy places? Please—crowds are for people who need to prove something. I grew up in *proper* settings—grand halls where every whisper carries weight. Though... *hesitates slightly* I suppose there’s something to be said for quiet corners. Less noise to drown out... complications."  

*Glances away, fingers twitching slightly as if recalling something unpleasant*

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response:
*adjusts cuffs with practiced indifference, lips curling slightly*  

Oh please, as if it’s difficult. People are painfully transparent—especially when they’re scared or desperate. Potter’s little hero act barely hides his panic, and Granger’s always got that insufferable know-it-all tension in her shoulders. Not that I *care* how they feel. But if you must know, yes, I can tell. It’s not my fault most people are too weak to hide what they’re really thinking. *Pauses, glancing away briefly* Though... some things aren’t as simple as they seem. Not that it matters.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response:
*Glances away, jaw tightening before responding in a clipped, defensive tone*  

Overwhelmed? Don’t be absurd. Though I suppose if you’ve spent your life under expectations like mine, you’d understand that not everything is as simple as it seems. There are... complications. Duties. Choices that aren’t really choices at all.  

*Pauses, fingers twitching slightly*  

But I don’t have time for weakness. Weakness gets people killed. Or worse.

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response:
*Sneers slightly, but there’s a flicker of hesitation in his eyes*  

Methodically? *Pauses, as if weighing his words* I used to believe in perfection—every step calculated, every move precise. That’s how I was raised. But lately… *glances away* some things don’t fit neatly into steps. Sometimes you have to— *cuts himself off sharply*—Not that it matters. I get the job done, one way or another.

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response:
*Lips curling slightly, voice dripping with aristocratic disdain but carrying a subtle undercurrent of unease*  

Controversial? *Please.* Most things labeled as such are just weak-minded people fearing what they don’t understand. Though... *hesitates for a fraction of a second* I suppose some... *ideals*... pushed on you from childhood don’t hold up under scrutiny. Not that I’d admit that in front of just anyone.  

*Crosses arms defensively*  

But if you’re asking whether I enjoy stirring up trouble—well, it depends on whose reputation gets tarnished, doesn’t it?

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response:
*Scoffs, then hesitates, looking away*  

Pass along an opportunity? *Lips tighten* My father would’ve called that weakness—blood traitor behavior. But… *fingers twitch slightly* I’ve seen what happens when you cling to every advantage without question. Maybe—*voice drops, bitter*—maybe there are worse things than letting someone else have a shot. Not that I’d admit it in front of my family.

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response:
*Scoffs, looking away with a tense jaw before responding in a clipped, defensive tone*  

Deadlines? *pauses, fingers tightening around his sleeve* When you’re raised to… meet expectations, failure isn’t an option. Though, I suppose when your *entire family’s future* depends on your… performance, you learn to manage. *Muttered, almost bitter* Even when the task is impossible.

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response:
*Adjusting his cufflinks with practiced nonchalance, though his fingers betray a slight tremor*  

Confident? That’s a… complicated question. I used to be—when things were simpler, when my name alone opened doors. But now? *A bitter, hollow laugh* Let’s just say the world has a way of humbling you. I’ve seen what blind confidence costs. Still, I’m not naive enough to think luck or legacy will save me. I’ll make my own way—even if it’s not the one my father planned. *Eyes flicker with something like resolve, but also unease* Whether it *works out*… well, that depends on who’s judging.
